frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The following scatterplot shows the size, in square feet, and the selling price, in thousands of dollars, for a sample of <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> houses for sale in a certain area. (a) Describe the association shown in the scatterplot.

(b) In the region, houses are considered large if they are greater than <math alttext="2,500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> square feet and expensive if the selling price is greater than <math alttext="300,000 dollars"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>300</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The following two-way table summarizes the houses in the sample. Large Not Large Total Expensive <math alttext="8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Not Expensive <math alttext="4"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="16"><mstyle><mrow><mn>16</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Total <math alttext="12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="18"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (i) Use the information in the table to construct a graphical display of the data. (ii) Assume there is no association between size (large, not large) and price (expensive, not expensive). Use the given totals to complete the following table with the expected number of houses for each classification if there was no association. Large Not Large Total Expensive <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Not Expensive <math alttext="20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Total <math alttext="12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="18"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

For associations displayed in the scatterplot, the strength of linear association is measured by the correlation coefficient. For the scatterplot of houses, <math alttext="r equals 0.82"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.82</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.For associations that are summarized in two-way tables, the strength of association is measured by the chi-square statistic. The formula for the chi-square statistic is <math alttext="chi square equals, the sum of the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, observed minus expected, close parenthesis, squared, and denominator expected, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>o</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>e</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where expected is the count assuming no association and observed is the count shown by the data. Greater values of <math alttext="chi square"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> indicate stronger association. For the table of counts in part (b), <math alttext="chi square equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Suppose the selling price for the most expensive house in the sample is decreased from <math alttext="489,000 dollars"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>489</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="325,000 dollars"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>325</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(i) What effect would the decrease have on the value of <math alttext="r"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your reasoning.(ii) What effect would the decrease have on the value of <math alttext="chi square"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>? Explain your reasoning.

(d) Based on your answer to part (c), explain one benefit and one drawback of using <math alttext="chi square"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> rather than <math alttext="r"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to measure the strength of an association.
